subject: Re: Quickscript in other countries
msgSnippet: I see the links are already given. As you can see Esperanto is fully phonetic but there is still a Quickscript AND Shavian version for the language. In Dutch
messageBody:
I see the links are already given. As you can see Esperanto is fully
phonetic but there is still a Quickscript AND Shavian version for the
language. In Dutch most words are said as they're written, but it
contains a lot of unnecessary letters. Also, you can write Shavian
and Quickscript a lot faster than you can latin letters as each
character only need one stroke.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Susan&BJ <suebee2000_miss@...>
wrote:
>
> Most other languages outside English are (almost) phonetic, so they
do not have a great need for a writing system like Shavian or
Quikskript. However they do have their own shorthand systems. By the
way I would be interested in seeing the Dutch versions of both.
>
> B. J.
>
> tim_rice09 <tim_rice09@...> wrote:
> The problem with adapting Quickscript to other languages
is that
> English is well, wierd. Only 2 of the cardinal vowels are present
and
> are quite off-glided. Also, Quickscript lacks letters for say the
> Spanish Ñ and the Russian soft sign. Not to mention the rolled R
which
> is needed for languages with both types of the sound. Are there any
> Armenians here?
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "ramsesoudt" <tommie22@>
> wrote:
> >
> > I'm very curious about how big Quikscript is in other countries.
For
> > example: are there any foreigners in this group? I'm from the
> > Netherlands, but because I speak English pretty well I came
across
> > Quikscript and learned it myself after that I learned to use
> Shavian.
> > After that, I transliterated Shavian for the use in Dutch and
some
> time
> > later I found a transliteration of Quikscript for use in Dutch.
> >
> > But I'm curious how big it is in other countries and if there are
> more
> > transliterations...
> >
>
>
>
>
>
>
> ---------------------------------
> Get your email and more, right on the new Yahoo.com
>
